p: How participants learned from site staff was reported as a key driver of IPT completion. Being alerted indirectly or directly to the risks of TB was recognized across interviews as being central to the success of IPT adherence. As TB and HIV are thought to have very similar symptoms, education at the clinics and in the communities was helpful for participants to differentiate between the two. Informal conversations with non-participants clarified for members of the research team that stigma associated with HIV symptoms are often conflated with symptoms of TBâ€”loss of weight, skin coloring, coughing, and going to the clinic often for medications. Sensitizing community members, one family member at a time, appeared to be a consistent refrain. One participant made it clear to our team that educating friends was important.
